title: Rory Stewart begins his campaign as an Independent to be next London mayor
text:
Rory Stewart, who has now resigned as a Conservative MP, has said that political parties are 'dragging towards the extremes' as he begins his campaign as an Independent to be next London mayor.

The ex-Tory Cabinet minister revealed his plans after claiming that mayors who belonged to political parties carry the 'baggage' of their manifestos with them.

He instead suggested that as an independent candidate he could 'really focus' on London's interests.

Rory Stewart, 46, has begun his campaign as an Independent to be next London mayor

Mr Stewart boldly revealed he was resigning as a member of the Conservative Party and as an MP while live on stage on Friday.

He later announced his intention to stand as an independent candidate in next year's race to be mayor of London.

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: 'I think British political parties are dragging towards the extremes. I think there is a gaping hole in the centre...

'I'm obviously not a partisan of Sadiq Khan's or indeed of any political party - I think that mayoral roles can be done very well by independents.

Mr Stewart has been highly critical of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's approach to Brexit

'And I think the danger of mayors being part of political parties is they carry the whole damage and the baggage of those manifestos with them.

'I would like to be a mayor of London that can really focus on London's interests rather than being tied to Jeremy Corbyn or Boris Johnson.'

In a swipe at the incumbent Mr Khan, Mr Stewart said he did not think he had 'made the most' of the role and that it was 'not clear' what his dreams are for London.

He added: 'I can make the role of mayor something bigger than it's been in the past - I think there's huge potential in the role of mayor of London.

'I think it's something that we see in cities like New York, I don't think we've begun to see the potential of it.'

There was anger today toward the BBC Today presenter Justin Webb who suggested Rory Stewart should not stand for mayor because he is a white man and an Old Etonian.

He went on to suggest that Mr Stewart standing in the race was not 'really 2020'.

Despite this, over the coming weeks, the 46-year-old intends to emulate his walk across Afghanistan in 2002 by touring each borough of London on foot as part of a listening mission before the campaign kicks off.

The Remain campaigner has been highly critical of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's approach to Brexit and voted against a no-deal exit.
description: The ex-Tory Cabinet minister said mayors who were part of political parties carry the 'baggage' of their manifestos with them and that Sadiq Khan had not 'made the most' of the role.
